intro: Otacanthus caeruleus, commonly known as the blue mistflower, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its showy, blue-violet flower heads. The plant typically grows in moist, well-drained soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Its foliage is lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its ornamental appeal. Otacanthus caeruleus is often used in gardens for its ability to attract pollinators like butterflies and bees.
